qas.question: Who identified gravity as a force?
Who came up with the concept that falling objects fell at the same speed regardless of weight?
How fast do objects fall on Earth?
Where was the measurment for the standard gravity on Earth taken?
What is an object's mass proportional to at the surface of the Earth?

answers.text: the force of gravity on an object

qas.question: Until the work of Galileo, what was not identified as a universal force?
Newton was instrumental in describing the characteristics of falling what?

plausible_answers.text: acceleration due to gravity towards the surface of the Earth

qas.question: What has a magnitude of about 8.81 meters per second squared?
What was identified as a universal force after the work of Galileo?

context: What we now call <b5_0><b8_0>gravity<b8_0/><b5_0/> was not identified as a universal force until the work of <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3>Isaac Newton<a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. Before Newton, the tendency for objects to fall towards the Earth was not understood to be related to the motions of celestial objects. <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3>Galileo<a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> was instrumental in describing the characteristics of falling <b6_0>objects<b6_0/> by determining that the acceleration of every object in free-fall was constant and independent of the mass of the object. Today, this <b7_0>acceleration due to gravity towards the surface of the Earth<b7_0/> is usually designated as  and has a magnitude of <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>about <a2_3>9.81 meters per second<a2_3/><a2_2/> squared<a2_1/><a2_0/> (this measurement is taken <a3_3>from <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>sea level<a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> and may vary depending on location), and points toward the center of the Earth. This observation means that <a4_1>the <a4_0><a4_2><a4_3>force of gravity<a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_0/> on an object<a4_1/> at the Earth's surface is directly proportional to the object's mass.
